newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Gippsland, others eye Mongolia gold mining.
newsitem.headline: Gippsland, others eye Mongolia gold mining.

text.p: Gippsland Resources Australia NL chairman John Telford said on Tuesday he was hopeful that his company would win the rights to develop the 40-tonne primary gold deposit at Boroo, Mongolia.
"We are hopeful about the outcome of the tender," Telford said in an address to the Asia Gold Congress currently being held in Hong Kong, adding that a decision was expected soon.
Mongolia's Mining Division director at the Ministry of Agriculture and Industry, Tsendiin Enkhbold, who was unable to attend the Congress at the last minute, requested Telford to present his speech.
According to Enkhbold, US firm Morrison Knedsen had also prepared a feasibility study to develop the Boroo primary deposit.
"In addition, Australian company Molopo Australia is working for confirmation of the Tsagaan Suvrag copper deposit reserves," Enkhbold added, noting that the copper deposit had a high gold content.
Three foreign companies from Russia and Canada were working to develop primary deposits in Mongolia, Enkhbold said.

He listed Mongolrostsvetmet, a Mongol-Russian joint venture at Eroo and Zamar, Canada's Mongolia Gold Co. Ltd at the Bumbat primary deposit and the Russian Yakutalmaz Co. Ltd at the Tavt vein deposit.
Mongolia Gold Resources Inc announced in June it would invest US$600,000 to develop the Bumbat mine and that construction was on schedule.
"In addition to that we have started detailed exploration work in Tsagaan Tsakhir primary deposit with the assistance of Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA)," Enkhbold said.
He added that RTZ-CRA was gathering information and conducting field studies in six areas of western and central Mongolia.
"Just recently the Australian mining company BHP has opened its representative office in Ulaanbaatar and applied to conduct copper exploration," he said.
Mongolia's newly elected democratic government is encouraging foreign investment in minerals to jump start economic growth, Enkhbold said.
